content:
WorkflowView Class

Definition

Provides a design surface, which renders a visual representation of process flow.

In this Article

[System.ComponentModel.ToolboxItem(false)]
[System.Obsolete("The System.Workflow.* types are deprecated.  Instead, please use the new types from System.Activities.*")]
[System.Workflow.ComponentModel.Design.ActivityDesignerTheme(typeof(System.Workflow.ComponentModel.Design.AmbientTheme), Xml="<AmbientTheme xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/winfx/2006/xaml/workflow" ApplyTo="System.Workflow.ComponentModel.Design.WorkflowView" ShowConfigErrors="True" DrawShadow="False" DrawGrayscale="False" DropIndicatorColor="0xFF006400" SelectionForeColor="0xFF0000FF" SelectionPatternColor="0xFF606060" ForeColor="0xFF808080" BackColor="0xFFFFFFFF" ShowGrid="False" GridColor="0xFFC0C0C0" TextQuality="Aliased" DrawRounded="True" ShowDesignerBorder="True" />")]
public class WorkflowView : System.Windows.Forms.UserControl, IServiceProvider, System.Windows.Forms.IMessageFilter

Remarks

Note

This material discusses types and namespaces that are obsolete. For more information, see Deprecated Types in Windows Workflow Foundation 4.5.

WorkflowView is the design surface which renders a visual representation of process flow described in workflow markup. WorkflowView offers a rich set of user interface functionality needed by the activity designers for rendering and for responding to various Windows-generated events. Also, the WorkflowView offers a set of common functions which can be used by all designers to perform certain activities.

Constructors

WorkflowView()

Initializes an instance of a WorkflowView.

public WorkflowView ();

WorkflowView(IServiceProvider)

Initializes an instance of a WorkflowView with the specified service provider.

public WorkflowView (IServiceProvider serviceProvider);
serviceProvider
IServiceProvider

An object that implements the IServiceProvider interface.

Properties

EnableFitToScreen

Enables the button on the design surface that, when clicked, changes the zoom level of the workflow design surface so that the entire workflow is displayed in the WorkflowView.

public bool EnableFitToScreen { get; set; }
Value
Boolean

true if the dynamic button is enabled; otherwise, false.

HScrollBar

Gets the horizontal scrollbar for the WorkflowView.

public System.Windows.Forms.HScrollBar HScrollBar { get; }
Value
HScrollBar

A ScrollBar you can use to adjust the settings and visibility of the horizontal scrollbar.

PrintDocument

Gets the PrintDocument associated with the WorkflowView.

public System.Drawing.Printing.PrintDocument PrintDocument { get; }
Value
PrintDocument

A PrintDocument object that sends output to a printer.

Remarks

Use the PrintDocument object to set the properties that describe how to print, and call the Print method to start the printing process.

PrintPreviewMode

Gets or sets the print preview mode of the WorkflowView.

public bool PrintPreviewMode { get; set; }
Value
Boolean

true if print preview mode is active; otherwise, false.

RootDesigner

Gets or sets the root designer for the WorkflowView.

public System.Workflow.ComponentModel.Design.ActivityDesigner RootDesigner { get; set; }
Value
ActivityDesigner

The ActivityDesigner associated with the WorkflowView.

Remarks

The root designer of the workflow is the designer associated with the design surface of the workflow. It contains all child designers, and subsequently all activities in the workflow.

ScrollPosition

Gets or sets the position of the scrollbar on the WorkflowView.

public System.Drawing.Point ScrollPosition { get; set; }
Value
Point

A point describing the location of the scrollbar in screen coordinates.

Remarks

Use the ScrollPosition to get or adjust the location of the scrollbar in the design surface.

ShadowDepth

Gets or sets the ShadowDepth for the WorkflowView.

public int ShadowDepth { get; set; }
Value
Int32

The shadow depth in pixels.

Remarks

Use the ShadowDepth to get or adjust the shadow depth of text shown on the workflow design surface.

ViewPortRectangle

Gets the current ViewPortRectangle for the WorkflowView.

public System.Drawing.Rectangle ViewPortRectangle { get; }
Value
Rectangle

A Rectangle that describes the area on the screen that is visible.

Remarks

The ViewPortRectangle contains the visible area of the workflow.

ViewPortSize

Gets the size of the visible area for the WorkflowView.

public System.Drawing.Size ViewPortSize { get; }
Value
Size

A Size that describes the visible area of the WorkflowView.

Remarks

Gets the size of the visible area of the WorkflowView.

VScrollBar

Gets the vertical scrollbar associated with the WorkflowView.

public System.Windows.Forms.VScrollBar VScrollBar { get; }
Value
VScrollBar

A ScrollBar you can use to adjust the settings and visibility of the horizontal scrollbar.

Remarks

Use VScrollBar to get the vertical scrollbar on the WorkflowView, which you can use to make user interface adjustments.

Zoom

Gets or sets the zoom level of the WorkflowView.

public int Zoom { get; set; }
Value
Int32

The zoom level of the WorkflowView.

Exceptions
NotSupportedException

If the zoom level is less than the minimum zoom level of the AmbientTheme

-or-

if the zoom level exceeds the maximum zoom level of the AmbientTheme.

Remarks

Use the zoom feature to enlarge or reduce the size of the components inside the WorkflowView. The AmbientTheme sets the minimum and maximum zoom levels for the WorkflowView.

Methods

AddDesignerMessageFilter(WorkflowDesignerMessageFilter)

Adds a WorkflowDesignerMessageFilter to the WorkflowView.

public void AddDesignerMessageFilter (System.Workflow.ComponentModel.Design.WorkflowDesignerMessageFilter designerMessageFilter);
designerMessageFilter
WorkflowDesignerMessageFilter

The WorkflowDesignerMessageFilter to add to the WorkflowView.

Remarks

A WorkflowDesignerMessageFilter is a component that handles messages from the WorkflowView.

Using the Strategy design pattern, the WorkflowView will pass messages to the WorkflowDesignerMessageFilter to be handled.

Mouse events, keyboard events, paint and layout events are passed on to a WorkflowDesignerMessageFilter associated with the WorkflowView.

ClientPointToLogical(Point)

Converts a Point from client coordinates to logical coordinates.

public System.Drawing.Point ClientPointToLogical (System.Drawing.Point clientPoint);
clientPoint
Point

The Point to convert from client coordinates to logical coordinates.

Returns
Point

The Point converted from client coordinates to logical coordinates.

Remarks

WorkflowView uses two coordinate spaces: logical and client:

  • Client coordinates are relative to the upper-left corner of the WorkflowView. The upper-left corner is 0,0; x and y coordinates increase vertically and horizontally in the viewable area. The client coordinate system is affected by the zoom level of the WorkflowView and by the scrollbar position.

  • In the logical coordinate system every object is always mapped to 0,0. The position vertically and horizontally is not affected by zoom or scrollbar position.

ClientRectangleToLogical(Rectangle)

Converts a Rectangle from client coordinates to logical coordinates.

public System.Drawing.Rectangle ClientRectangleToLogical (System.Drawing.Rectangle rectangle);
rectangle
Rectangle

The Rectangle to convert from client to logical coordinates.

Returns
Rectangle

The Rectangle converted from client coordinates to logical coordinates.

Remarks

WorkflowView uses two coordinate spaces: logical and client:

  • Client coordinates are relative to the upper-left corner of the WorkflowView. The upper-left corner is 0,0; x and y coordinates increase vertically and horizontally in the viewable area. The client coordinate system is affected by the zoom level of the WorkflowView and by the scrollbar position.

    In the logical coordinate system every object is always mapped to 0,0. The position vertically and horizontally is not affected by zoom or scrollbar position.

ClientSizeToLogical(Size)

Converts a Size from client to logical coordinates.

public System.Drawing.Size ClientSizeToLogical (System.Drawing.Size clientSize);
clientSize
Size

The Size to convert from client to logical coordinates.

Returns
Size

The Size converted from client coordinates to logical coordinates.

Remarks

WorkflowView uses two coordinate spaces: logical and client:

  • Client coordinates are relative to the upper-left corner of the WorkflowView. The upper-left corner is 0,0; x and y coordinates increase vertically and horizontally in the viewable area. The client coordinate system is affected by the zoom level of the WorkflowView and by the scrollbar position.

    In the logical coordinate system every object is always mapped to 0,0. The position vertically and horizontally is not affected by zoom or scrollbar position.

CreateAccessibilityInstance()

Creates a new AccessibleObject for the WorkflowView.

protected override System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleObject CreateAccessibilityInstance ();
Returns
AccessibleObject

A new AccessibleObject for the WorkflowView.

Remarks

If you do not explicitly call the CreateAccessibilityInstance method, it will be called when the AccessibleObject property is referenced.

Note

To create a AccessibleObject, you must add a reference to the Accessibility assembly installed with the .NET Framework.

Dispose(Boolean)

Releases the unmanaged resources used by the WorkflowView and optionally releases the managed resources.

protected override void Dispose (bool disposing);
disposing
Boolean

true to release both managed and unmanaged resources; false to release only unmanaged resources.

Remarks

When the disposing parameter is true, this method releases all resources held by any managed objects that this WorkflowView references. This method invokes the Dispose() method of each referenced object.

For more information about Dispose and Finalize, see Cleaning Up Unmanaged Resources and Overriding the Finalize Method.

EnsureVisible(Object)

Ensures that the Object passed is visible, expanding parent objects and scrolling the WorkflowView as necessary.

public void EnsureVisible (object selectableObject);
selectableObject
Object

The object to make visible.

Exceptions
ArgumentNullException

selectableObject is a null reference (Nothing in Visual Basic).

Remarks

Use EnsureVisible when you are working with an object in the workflow that requires user interface cues. EnsureVisible will expand parent objects and scroll the WorkflowView as necessary to make the object visible on the designer.

FitToScreenSize()

Changes the zoom level of the workflow design surface so that the entire workflow is displayed in the WorkflowView.

public void FitToScreenSize ();

Remarks

The actual zoom level is dependent upon the settings of the user's workflow designer.

FitToWorkflowSize()

Changes the zoom level to one hundred percent to display the full size of the workflow in the WorkflowView.

public void FitToWorkflowSize ();

GetService(Type)

Gets the service object of the specified type, if it is available.

protected override object GetService (Type serviceType);
serviceType
Type

The Type of the service to retrieve.

Returns
Object

If the serviceType is typeof(CommandID) then GetService returns a specific CommandID; otherwise, GetService returns a Object implementing the requested service, or a null reference (Nothing in Visual Basic) if the service cannot be resolved.

Remarks

GetService returns a Object implementing the requested service, or a null reference (Nothing) if the service cannot be resolved.

InvalidateClientRectangle(Rectangle)

Invalidates the specified Rectangle and causes it to be repainted.

public void InvalidateClientRectangle (System.Drawing.Rectangle clientRectangle);
clientRectangle
Rectangle

The Rectangle, in client coordinates, to invalidate and cause to be repainted.

Remarks

Use InvalidateClientRectangle to cause a Rectangle, in client coordinates, to be added to the update region.

InvalidateLogicalRectangle(Rectangle)

Invalidates the specified Rectangle and causes it to be repainted.

public void InvalidateLogicalRectangle (System.Drawing.Rectangle logicalRectangle);
logicalRectangle
Rectangle

The Rectangle, in logical coordinates, to invalidate and cause to be repainted.

Remarks

Use InvalidateLogicalRectangle to cause a Rectangle, in logical coordinates, to be added to the update region.

LoadViewState(Stream)

Restores view-state information from a binary stream.

public void LoadViewState (System.IO.Stream viewState);
viewState
Stream

A BinaryReader used to restore the view state.

Remarks

LoadViewState restores view-state information previously saved by calling the SaveViewState method.

Override this method when you need to customize how a custom designer restores its view-state.

OnControlAdded(ControlEventArgs)

Occurs when a control is added to the WorkflowView.

protected override void OnControlAdded (System.Windows.Forms.ControlEventArgs e);
e
ControlEventArgs

A ControlEventArgs that contains the event data.

Exceptions
InvalidOperationException

If the control added is not a stem.Workflow.ComponentModel.Design.WorkflowView.HScrollBar* or stem.Workflow.ComponentModel.Design.WorkflowView.VScrollBar*

Remarks

OnControlAdded is called when a child control is added to the WorkflowView. The only child controls allowed are HScrollBar and VScrollBar controls.

OnDragDrop(DragEventArgs)

Occurs when a dragged item is dropped onto the WorkflowView.

protected override void OnDragDrop (System.Windows.Forms.DragEventArgs dragEventArgs);
dragEventArgs
DragEventArgs

A DragEventArgs that provides data for the event.

Remarks

OnDragDrop occurs when the user releases the mouse button over the WorkflowView during a drag operation.

OnDragEnter(DragEventArgs)

Occurs when an item is dragged into the WorkflowView bounds.

protected override void OnDragEnter (System.Windows.Forms.DragEventArgs dragEventArgs);
dragEventArgs
DragEventArgs

A DragEventArgs that provides data for the event.

Remarks

OnDragEnter occurs when the user first drags the mouse cursor over the WorkflowView during a drag operation.

OnDragLeave(EventArgs)

Occurs when the cursor leaves the WorkflowView during a drag operation.

protected override void OnDragLeave (EventArgs e);
e
EventArgs

A EventArgs that provides data for the event.

Remarks

OnDragLeave occurs when the user drags the mouse cursor out of the WorkflowView during a drag operation.

OnDragOver(DragEventArgs)

Occurs when a drag-drop operation is in progress and the pointer is within the WorkflowView bounds.

protected override void OnDragOver (System.Windows.Forms.DragEventArgs dragEventArgs);
dragEventArgs
DragEventArgs

A DragEventArgs that provides data for the event.

Remarks

OnDragOver occurs when the mouse cursor moves within bounds of the WorkflowView.

OnGiveFeedback(GiveFeedbackEventArgs)

Occurs during a drag operation.

protected override void OnGiveFeedback (System.Windows.Forms.GiveFeedbackEventArgs gfbevent);
gfbevent
GiveFeedbackEventArgs

A GiveFeedbackEventArgs that provides data for the event.

Remarks

OnGiveFeedback occurs when a drag operation is started. OnGiveFeedback allows the source of a drag operation to modify the appearance of the mouse pointer in order to give the user visual feedback during a drag operation.

OnKeyDown(KeyEventArgs)

Occurs when a key is pressed while the WorkflowView has focus.

protected override void OnKeyDown (System.Windows.Forms.KeyEventArgs e);
e
KeyEventArgs

A KeyEventArgs that provides data for the event.

Remarks

OnKeyDown occurs when a key is pressed while the WorkflowView has focus.

OnKeyUp(KeyEventArgs)

Occurs when a key is released while the WorkflowView has focus.

protected override void OnKeyUp (System.Windows.Forms.KeyEventArgs e);
e
KeyEventArgs

A KeyEventArgs that provides data about the event.

Remarks

OnKeyUp occurs when a key is released while the WorkflowView has focus.

OnLayout(LayoutEventArgs)

Occurs when the WorkflowView should reposition child controls.

protected override void OnLayout (System.Windows.Forms.LayoutEventArgs levent);
levent
LayoutEventArgs

A LayoutEventArgs that provides data for the event.

Remarks

OnLayout occurs when child controls are added or removed, when the bounds of the WorkflowView changes, and when other changes occur that can affect the layout of the WorkflowView.

OnMouseCaptureChanged(EventArgs)

Occurs when the items selected by dragging the mouse changes.

protected override void OnMouseCaptureChanged (EventArgs e);
e
EventArgs

A EventArgs that provides data about the event.

Remarks

OnMouseCaptureChanged occurs when the user makes a selection with the mouse that differs from any existing selection.

OnMouseDoubleClick(MouseEventArgs)

Occurs when the WorkflowView is double-clicked.

protected override void OnMouseDoubleClick (System.Windows.Forms.MouseEventArgs e);
e
MouseEventArgs

A MouseEventArgs that contains information about the event.

Remarks

The double-click is determined by the mouse settings of the operating system. The user can set the time between clicks of a mouse button that should be considered a double-click rather than two clicks.

OnMouseDown(MouseEventArgs)

Occurs when the mouse pointer is over the WorkflowView and a mouse button is pressed.

protected override void OnMouseDown (System.Windows.Forms.MouseEventArgs e);
e
MouseEventArgs

A MouseEventArgs that contains information about the event.

Remarks

Mouse events occur in the following order:

1.OnMouseEnter

2.OnMouseMove

3.OnMouseHover/ OnMouseDown or OnMouseWheel

4.OnMouseUp

5.OnMouseLeave

OnMouseEnter occurs when the mouse pointer enters the WorkflowView.

OnMouseDown occurs when the mouse pointer is over the WorkflowView and a mouse button is pressed.

OnMouseEnter(EventArgs)

Occurs when the mouse pointer enters the WorkflowView.

protected override void OnMouseEnter (EventArgs e);
e
EventArgs

An EventArgs that contains information about the event.

Remarks

Mouse events occur in the following order:

1.OnMouseEnter

2.OnMouseMove

3.OnMouseHover or OnMouseDown or OnMouseWheel

4.OnMouseUp

5.OnMouseLeave

OnMouseEnter occurs when the mouse pointer enters the WorkflowView.

OnMouseHover(EventArgs)

e
EventArgs

A EventArgs that contains information about the event.

Remarks

Mouse events occur in the following order:

1.OnMouseEnter

2.OnMouseMove

3.OnMouseHover or OnMouseDown or OnMouseWheel

4.OnMouseUp

5.OnMouseLeave

OnMouseHover occurs when the mouse pointer hovers over the WorkflowView.

OnQueryContinueDrag(QueryContinueDragEventArgs)

Occurs during a drag operation and allows the drag source to determine whether the drag option should be canceled.

protected override void OnQueryContinueDrag (System.Windows.Forms.QueryContinueDragEventArgs qcdevent);
qcdevent
QueryContinueDragEventArgs

A QueryContinueDragEventArgs that contains information about the event.

Remarks

The OnQueryContinueDrag event is raised when there is a change in the keyboard or mouse button state during a drag operation. The OnQueryContinueDrag event allows the drag source to determine whether the drag operation should be canceled.

Events related to drag operations are raised when the control is a valid drop target. The OnGiveFeedback event is raised with the drag effect specified. For a list of drag effects, see the DragDropEffects enumeration.

Changes in the mouse cursor position, keyboard state, and mouse button state are tracked.

  • If the user moves out of a window, the OnDragLeave event is raised.

  • If the mouse enters another control, the OnDragEnter for that control is raised.

  • If the mouse moves but stays within the same control, the OnDragOver event is raised.

    If there is a change in the keyboard or mouse button state, the OnQueryContinueDrag event is raised and determines whether to continue the drag, to drop the data, or to cancel the operation based on the value of the Action property of the event QueryContinueDragEventArgs.

    If the value is DragAction.Continue, the OnDragOver event is raised to continue the operation and the OnGiveFeedback event is raised with the new effect so appropriate visual feedback can be set. For a list of valid drop effects, see the DragDropEffects enumeration.

Note

The OnDragOver and OnGiveFeedback events are paired so that as the mouse moves across the drop target, the user is given the most up-to-date feedback on the mouse position.

If the value is DragAction.Drop, the drop effect value is returned to the source, so the source application can perform the appropriate operation on the source data; for example, cut the data if the operation was a move.

If the value is DragAction.Cancel, the OnDragLeave event is raised.

By default, the OnQueryContinueDrag event sets Action to DragAction.Cancel if the ESC key was pressed and sets Action to DragAction.Drop if the left, middle, or right mouse button is pressed.

ScreenPointToLogical(Point)

Converts a Point from screen coordinates to logical coordinates.

public System.Drawing.Point ScreenPointToLogical (System.Drawing.Point screenPoint);
screenPoint
Point

The Point to convert from screen coordinates to logical coordinates.

Returns
Point

The Point converted from screen coordinates to logical coordinates.

Remarks

WorkflowView uses two coordinate spaces: logical and client:

Client coordinates are relative to the upper-left corner of the WorkflowView. The upper-left corner is 0,0; x and y coordinates increase vertically and horizontally in the viewable area. The client coordinate system is affected by the zoom level of the WorkflowView and by the scrollbar position.

In the logical coordinate system every object is always mapped to 0,0. The position vertically and horizontally is not affected by zoom or scrollbar position.

The WndProc method corresponds exactly to the Windows WindowProc function. For more information about processing Windows messages, see the WindowProc function documentation in the Windows Platform SDK reference located in the MSDN library.
